titleStmt.title: To CAPTAIN HENRY CHADS,Henry Chads (1819-1906; Dictionary of National Biography), captain, 1848, son of Sir Henry Ducie Chads. Sir Henry, a Rear-Admiral, was commander-in-chief at Cork, 1856-8, and his son was Flag-Captain to his father at Queenstown. 31 AUGUST 1858

dateline.placeName: Imperial Hotel, CorkCD arrived in Cork, 30 Aug, from Belfast and gave three Readings there; he was in Limerick, 1 Sep.

body.p: Mr. Charles Dickens presents his compliments to Captain Chads, and is very cordially obliged by his kind letter. It would have afforded Mr. Dickens the greatest pleasure and interest, if he could possibly have accepted the courteous invitationCD consistently refused all offers of hospitality during the Readings. of Captain Chads. But unfortunately his time is so fully occupied, that he has only one poor quarter of an hour for Queenstown.Now Cobh, some 12 miles by road south-east of Cork.
